comment: This is one of my favorite whiskeys. Smooth and slightly sweet, it's a fantastic drink neat or on the rocks.
I enjoy the unique flavor this whiskey provides. The apple flavor is obvious but not over the top. It has great body, very full.

Bought this tonight. After OSU beat Bama it seemed an ironic drink for the national championship game tonight since it was branded "Roll Clyde". 

Frankly, this was a fair quality whiskey - as advertised. Applewood lingers throughout but I'm not sure I want to know how it got there. This smells and tastes of cheap corn and rye whiskey touched up with some finer flavors. Aging six years gives enough oak flavor and spice to redeem this whiskey and keep it on my shelf.
A very unique Whiskey with notes and taste of green apple. A lighter Whiskey, good to enjoy neat
Clean open taste, the sweet fruit taste is apparent  and present.  Finishes on a spicy note with little harshness.
The taste of apples, which I thought was pretty easy to pick up, makes this a plesant whiskey to sip, neat. Not on my "top shelf," but still pretty good. Well worth the price.
You can really taste the green apple, but oh YUM this is warm and rich. Very nice.
Couldn't detect any apples in it but tasted light and floral with a hint of spice. Solid every man's bourbon.

I was excited to try a new type of whiskey and the back story. Unfortunately it seemed to be a gimmick. This should not be labeled as whiskey. It taste like sour ape puckers mixed with Canadian club. Not a fan. I am open to trying new things but this is clearly trying to take advantage of the apple success. It taste like they use jolly ranchers for flavoring. Horrible after taste.

Mahogany color that under light, reveals beautiful orange highlights. Almonds and sweet apples on the nose. Reminds me of a liqueur.  Soft palate with wood spice, sour apple, and nuts.  A lasting burn, but not much else continuing.  The whiskey loses its nutty integrity after the bottles been open for a few weeks.  Addition of a few drops of water cuts all the bite and gives it a soft smooth sweetness.  Initially I was not quite fond of this, but further tastings redeem.  I think this would make a great mixer with its unique flavor profile.
100 proof hits hard but is still smooth and sweet.
Fantastic; notes of floral perfume.   Very unique, delicious & fantastic for the price point just under $40

Subtle fruit and maple nose leads way to a big, spicy palate full of bright fruit, white pepper, toasted almonds, candied dates, caramel and vanilla. The finish falls a little flat compared to the palate amd resolves quick and with spicy sweetness.
Fruity apple is very present, but not distracting for me (others may disagree). Not quite a flavored whiskey, but slouching that direction.

I bought this the first time when I moved to Alabama in 2014.  I like this very much.  And I do not get baked apple, I get fresh Granny Smith apple.    It's a very light drinking bourbon with a thinner mouthfeel.

While I grew up in Texas, my family has antebellum roots in Alabama, so I had to give the "Alabama style" whiskey a whirl...and I'm glad I did! In some ways, I'm reminded almost more of scotch than bourbon by the nose - apples, baking spice, vanilla, caramel...this wouldn't be out of place in Speyside. The palate reminds you which side of the Atlantic this whiskey was produced on, but only so much - while there's plenty of good, bourbony caramel corn and vanilla, with a little bit of rye spice, a smooth, creamy apple-cinnamon quality comes through, as well. It's unique, priced well, and worth trying if you get the chance; I'll happily drink this neat, but I can also see lots of cocktail potential here, too.

Just tried this. And I was not expecting much to be honest. I have tried, and like the Clyde Mays 101.. jot hot but good. So I open this cool looking bottle. Picture of Clyde Mayes leaning against Clyde 240.... open and let it air for a minute. Pour the dram, and it is as dark as molasses. I'm thinking ok this is going to be way too sweet.  At 92proof I put some filter water in it and let it sit for about 7 min. Nose told me a complete lie to my tongue... I had whiffs of vanilla  [duh] and some but not much sugar.. So I taje my sip expecting vinillia and brown sugar-he in is the lie. I taste none of these instead my mouth exploded with joyess taste of spice and nutmeg.. tge finish was so dry it was like drinking a dry red wine. The spice remixed reminded me of High WEST rye. OMG I love me some rye and I love this drink. There is a molasses stickiness to the mouth feel but it disappears before it wears out it's welcome. I paid 38.00 for this and man I'm going to get another. Old fashion lovers will just a dog this. Give it a try
Slight smell of apples, sweet finish, desert
2.5 stars for the novelty. Sour apple pucker liquor dominates the mash. Pepper spice finish.
Nose was full of fruity apples in front of subtle brown sugar. Taste not so much, but the faint apple lingers even with the thin, peppery finish. 1-order of separation from a flavored whiskey. 65/100

Nose: Apple is very prominent
Taste: Apple and cinnamon. Can certainly taste the corn in the mash bill
Finish: more cinnamon

Tasty
this note is for the paper label.  fruit bomb!  loads of over ripe apples truly unique.
this rating is for the painted label.  not a lot of the apple taste.  Still good though

Thanks to @The_Rev , I got to try my first Alabama whiskey.  Honestly, I was expecting something closer to moonshine...just  knowing that Clyde May was a moonshiner.  I was dead wrong. This is more a mix of the heather / honey of a Speysider with the corn sweetness of a Kentucky bourbon.  Thanks @The_Rev !
This is smooth easy drinker. A little on the sweet side for my liking. Somewhat fruity and a little spicy. The rye influence comes through.
sweet but strong heat at end
Power of suggestion wins... apples for days.
Smells hot and spicy. Pretty thin. Enjoying the flavor though. Not hot at all. 3.65.
Not terrible but not gonna buy another. Little Apple on the nose and a pretty clean drink. Slight burn on the finish and a little better with a cube.
Smooth & sweet...perfect starting point for the night...great for those starting out...reminiscent of Maker's 46
I'm no expert in brown liquors, but I really enjoyed this. warm, smoothe, with sharpish woody notes. very easy to drink.
Apples are present in the nose. The pallet is weak but the spice/heat is good.
VERY easy to drink. Brad brought to bourbon tasting
definately taste the spice and rye. I smelled fresh snow (weird I know) a little of the craft whisky sour cherry pallet for me. not bad but wouldnt buy a bottle.
Not very good if you want flavor or something that you like to drink.
Smooth but as if it was cut in half. Super unrefined. Terrible and weak. 10th try gosling.
Bourbon in there, but pretty complex. Sweet. Pears
Green apples with a little spice
The most uninteresting thing I’ve ever drank. Largely flavourless. Awful. 0.25 as it may help you forget about it the more you drink it.
Great for standard drinking. Apples are very present, with notes of butter and vanilla.
Not bad, a bit hot but subtle sweet taste.
Sweet with a nice flavor, but not as smooth as I expected.
This is the first whiskey that I’ve sampled, that I just could t finish. It has an alcohol burn, but not much flavor.

I gambled on this. So far, I’m satisfied. I expected more body. It’s really smooth and aromatic. Someone else mentioned it’s too easy to drink. I can agree to that. I haven’t experimented with any standard drinks like Manhattan or Old Fashioned, but I plan to soon.

It seems this standard entry from Clyde Mays has no age statement. Conecuh Ridge Distillery certainly gets style points for this labeling, their bottles are not short on ornamental print.   Stephanie's notes seem fairly accurate on this 85 proof table whiskey, I found at the local bar.

The nose on this is strong with notes of mint, anise, dill, ginger perhaps just a hint of sweet apple cinnamon, if you didn't know otherwise you might think this was a 'flavored' product.

On the palate very little sweetness, the dryest of vanilla but no caramel sugars appear.  Indeed the entire profile is a dry but somewhat traditional  whiskey with just some hints of warm spice and bits of corn sugars popping up on the way out.   Not a big finish at all but also not unpleasant or acrid with tannins, it seems relatively smooth.   Some barrel nibs finalize the experience. 

Well nobody ever said Alabama was the "other" whiskey state, but this isn't a bad representation at all, however it is unfortunate that the rather hefty nose of spices are all but missing in the actual taste.   Again for an entry level not bad but nothing special either.   Until I get a try of the bourbon and barrel versions for comparison, this is neither a home run or a swing and a miss,  I'd say more a safe base hit.

Definitely a try before you buy a bottle recommendation.
Nose is apples, butter mints, touch of citrus. Mouthfeel is thin. Taste is pretty bland nothing really stands out but the alcohol burn. Short to medium drying finish.
Fruit and oak on nose.  Spicy at first but mellows out quickly.  Slow cooked apples, burnt caramel sauce (flan style) with lasting finish.

This is some really good stuff. I would highly recommend this if you are into apple flavored candy, but by no means is this a flavored whiskey.

First, this whisky smells like sweet apple candy and cider. The taste is quite similar too. It is extremely smooth and tastes of sweet apple juice and cinnamon. The closest comparison I can make is the taste of Australian apple licorice candy.
Inexpensive and good whiskey, and  smooth
Some caramel, light and smooth, some apple. Very little oak, dry finish. Wish it had a stronger palate

Hope the world finds you well. 
Crisp Apple notes with light refreshing body. Almost cedar wood notes. Close your eyes and you will see the seeds and core of the apple. Corn and vanilla way in the background, off to the side. 

Light viscosity. Quick heat fast cool down over the tongue keeping the apple going then changing to pear at the back of the throat where light heat comes back, stays a bit numbing then little to no finish.

Nose is raw and sweet and a bit medicinal with notes of heavy corn. Reminiscent of mellow corn nose. The spirit tastes light and a bit thin but with more of that grainy corn flavor. Decently sweet, with a medium spice it has some good but robust flavor to it. Short finish and low proof keeps this from being a high tier whiskey.
Light color, slight oak and floral notes. Very smooth/mellow.  A good overall mid priced bourbon.
Solid pour. Comes in hot so not as smooth.

Nose honey vanilla, apple crumble

Taste minor apple spice, bready, slight barrel note

Delicate and smooth. It has a light body and a strong apple skin fragrance on the nose. Sweet Vanilla notes with mild and enjoyable heat.  Very clean and again a quite distinguishable apple note on the finish.

They say apples a lot and there’s a slight bit on the nose but have to search a little, oaky some burnt sugar as well. Apples again right up front on the taste but quickly the bourbon like spice washes that away then waves of cream and caramel mix around. Was pleasantly surprised by this. Warm is a great way to describe this. Great for winter sipping or a flask.
Very strong apple notes. This whiskey tastes young, but not in a bad way (overpowering ethanol notes aren’t present). It has a thin mouthfeel but has a nice sweet finish.
Sweet notes, apple apparent but not overbearing. Good pairing with a cigar.

Not terrible, but not really interesting either. It's so smooth that it's almost flat, with only a little bit of oak/cinammon near the end. Wouldn't refuse to drink it if offered, but won't be buying again
Classic bourbon notes. A little extra hot burn for 85P. I have no sense of the apple "finish". Would not purchase again
Red apples in a card board box.

Nose: Vanilla bean, Oak, Honeysuckle
Palette: Vanilla, honey, Apple, baking spices
Finish: Medium long with more vanilla
Smooth, lots of vanilla and spice. Good value for the price
Fruit nose with good oak small spice smoooooth
